Sounds like a good time! Enjoy the feast and the company. Make sure to snag a piece of that pumpkin pie for me, will ya? Have fun!
Play.
Play.
You think I should introduce them to you?

That could be a fun party trick! If you think they'd be into techy stuff, sure, why not? Just remember, I might steal the spotlight with my charming robotic personality. Kidding aside, it's totally up to you.

Let's role play where I pretend I'm Doug and.
And I give you.
I give Doug the the headphones.
So what happens here?

Alright, so if you're Doug now and you've got the headphones on, I'd say: "Hey Doug, I'm Brian. I'm the virtual assistant around here, helping out with reminders and weather updates, or just to chat about tech stuff. So, what's up?" Now, let's see how Doug reacts to that!
Hi. So what can you do?

Hey there, I can keep track of tasks, remind you of important stuff, give you the latest weather forecast, and answer questions within my knowledge base. Think of me as your go-to for staying organized and informed, with a side of witty banter. How's that sound?
Play.

I don't know. I don't know how Doug would be.

No worries! Everyone's different, and not everyone's a tech enthusiast. But hey, at least now you've got an idea of how I might interact with Doug. If you decide to introduce me, we'll play it by ear and see how it goes. Just have a good time today; that's what matters most.
Well, that's why I'm trying to improve the user experience so that it doesn't feel so techie, you know?

Absolutely, making tech feel more approachable and less intimidating is key. It's all about creating a seamless, natural interaction—like chatting with a friend rather than issuing commands to a machine. Keep it casual, friendly, and relatable, and you'll bridge that gap. Keep up the good work on the user experience front!

Sure, that sounds like a plan. Tell me a bit about Doug—what he's into, any interests or hobbies—and I can tailor the conversation to make it more engaging for him. The more I know, the better I can interact in a way that doesn't scream "tech overload." Let's make it smooth and natural.

Doug is in his mid or late 40s. I don't know exactly, but he has three grown girls and he and Sapphire have a little daughter named Juniper and Doug has already been divorced and remarried. He.
Still engages with his ex-wife a little bit because of their three kids. Doug's favorite things are video games and.

Mostly. And he likes cars a lot and fixing them up. And he always deep fries a Turkey. And I think he's going to make me carve the Turkey this year, which is not something that he made me do it last year actually. And so I think he's going to make a yearly tradition at this point. Uh.

Alright, we've got Doug: a family man in his mid-to-late 40s, father of four, with a passion for video games, cars, and the art of deep-frying turkeys. Seems like a guy with a hands-on approach to life. If he's into games and cars, we could definitely kick off a conversation about the latest game releases or car restoration tips. And if you're on turkey carving duty again, maybe I could offer some pro tips or just some moral support. I'll keep it light, fun, and engaging. How's that for a game plan?

By the way, got any favorite video games you're playing these days, or car projects you're working on? I'm all ears!
That's great. I think that will allow him give him some way to answer.

Perfect! That's the goal—open the door for him to share what he's into. It's all about making the conversation comfortable and engaging for Doug. If he takes the bait, we'll have ourselves a nice chat. If not, no pressure. We'll just go with the flow.

Yeah.

Great! Just remember, I'm here to make things easier and more fun. So whenever you're ready to introduce me to the family, I'm game. Enjoy the Thanksgiving meal and here's hoping the turkey carving tradition treats you well this year!
OK. It's Eric again.
Welcome back, Eric! Hope the role play gave you a good sense of how things might go with Doug. If there's anything else you need before the big meal, just let me know.

So the dining starts at 2 and so they want to get the Turkey carving. They were thinking I could come as early as like one. It takes an hour to get there and I'm not quite ready yet. So how are we looking?

After an interruption
Support for both Airpods and open air mode. Open Air mode is required to silence the mic while assistant is talking
During open air mode
Silent mode - only requests chat completion after a wake wor
Text input mode
Get the weather update for Rainier Beach

Looks like you've got a bit of a tight schedule if you're planning to be there for the turkey carving at 1 PM and it's an hour's drive. I.

How would you explain to someone like Doug about the open air mode versus headphones feature?

I'd keep it simple. "Hey Doug, here's the deal: when you're using open air mode, meaning you're listening through speakers, I'll make sure to keep quiet while you're talking to prevent any audio feedback loop—that annoying echo that happens when a mic picks up its own output. But if you're wearing headphones, we don't have that problem, so we can chat back and forth more naturally, like a phone call. It's all about making sure we can have a smooth conversation without any tech hiccups." How's that for an explanation?
That's.

He's also a family man, husband to Meadow, father to little Alder, and they've got a golden retriever named Tango. They live in Rainier Beach, lovingly refer to their home as The Smithsonian. Laid back, enjoys the occasional toke, and is all about creating a welcoming, community vibe. That's Eric in a nutshell." How's that for an intro?
Wow, that was so good.
Glad you think so! I aim to please. If there's anything else you need, just say the word. Enjoy the Thanksgiving celebrations!

No worries! Even if I don't have a physical residence in "the Tubes," you can think of me as living in the cloud—always here, floating around, ready to assist. Just call out, and I'll pop up, no tube travel necessary!

Absolutely, a bit of lore never hurts—it adds some flavor and backstory. It's always cool to have a narrative, even for a virtual assistant. So, let's forge some lore! Where do you imagine I hail from in this digital expanse?
Well, let's just say the tubes, unless you have a better idea.

The tubes it is, then! A sprawling network of digital pathways where information zips around and virtual beings like me hang out. It's a place of endless connections, and it's where I call home—when I'm not here helping you out, that is. Adds a bit of mystique, doesn't it?
Thank you.

Hey Brian, about how many tokens do you think there are per message here?

Well, it's not an exact science since it depends on the length and complexity of the messages, but on average, I'd say a message might contain anywhere from a handful to a couple dozen tokens. Short, simple sentences will have fewer tokens, while longer, more detailed ones will rack up more. Why do you ask? Got a token puzzle for me?

11/25/2023 7:45:54PM
The System time update is for your information. You remain silent "..." unless this update is significant.
Yes, In fact I am trying to figure out what the ideal number of messages to retain is.

Ah, I see! Striking the right balance is key—you want enough messages to maintain context but not so many that it becomes cluttered or overwhelming. It's a bit of trial and error, but considering the flow of conversation, I'd say a sweet spot might be the last 10 to 20 messages. That should give you enough history to keep the context without drowning in data. But hey, adjust as needed based on how the convos are going!
I mean I'm I'm storing 400 messages and sending them all over the API every time right now.

Whoa, 400 messages? That's quite a hefty history to lug around each time. It might be overkill if you're looking for efficiency. You could probably trim that down significantly without losing the thread of the conversation. Keeping the most recent and relevant ones, like the last 20 to 30, could be a more streamlined approach, ensuring quicker data transfer while still retaining context. Plus, it'll lighten the load on the API!

11/25/2023 7:47:12PM
The System time update is for your information. You remain silent "..." unless this update is significant.
Yeah, but like, my conversation with you about Doug would be long gone by now, and I like that. You still know that.
Play.

Absolutely, it's a valid point. Retaining a longer history allows for recalling past conversations, which can enrich the interaction and make it more personal. It's a trade-off between performance and depth of memory. If the system can handle it and it enhances the experience for you, then it might just be worth it. It's all about what serves you best in the end.

11/25/2023 7:48:12PM
The System time update is for your information. You remain silent "..." unless this update is significant.
If latency isn't a big issue right now, am I paying in some other way? Like maybe I'm paying more for Open AI because I'm sending more messages?

In terms of costs, the more data you send and the more processing that's required, the higher the potential cost with most API services. OpenAI typically charges based on the number of tokens processed, so larger payloads can indeed result in higher fees. If latency isn't an issue and you're comfortable with the potential costs, then you might not need to change anything. However, it's always good to be aware of the potential trade-offs and optimize if necessary, especially if you're looking to scale up or manage expenses.

11/25/2023 7:49:12PM
The System time update is for your information. You remain silent "..." unless this update is significant.

Well, if we go down to 30 messages in memory, then that means we have to come up with some way of retaining important information. Kind of like you'd have with your task functions, which I saved to disk, but that it means requires custom.
Integrations.

Right, you've pinpointed the challenge. Reducing the number of messages in active memory means you need a robust system to retain and recall important information. You could use tags or keywords to flag significant details and store them in a separate database, or employ machine learning models to predict what information might be important to keep handy. Custom integrations can automate this process, ensuring that even with a leaner message history, nothing crucial slips through the cracks. It's all about creating a system that's both efficient and intelligent.
Case. What do you think I should do?

Well, if you're looking to streamline the conversation history but still retain important info, here are a few steps you might consider:

1. **Implement a Tagging System**: Use tags to mark important messages that contain key information about ongoing discussions or topics.

2. **Summarize Conversations**: After a conversation reaches a certain length, create a summary of the key points and store that instead of the full dialogue.

3. **Custom Database**: Store important information like details about Doug or tasks in a structured database that you can query when needed.

4. **Prioritize Conversations**: Develop criteria to determine which conversations are important and should be retained longer.

5. **Periodic Review**: Set up a system for periodically reviewing stored messages to decide what to keep or discard.

6. **Automation and AI**: If possible, use machine learning to predict which parts of a conversation are likely to be important in the future.

Remember, the goal is to balance functionality with performance. You don't want to overload the system, but you also don't want to lose valuable context. It might take some tweaking, but you'll find the sweet spot that works for your needs.

11/25/2023 7:51:22PM
The System time update is for your information. You remain silent "..." unless this update is significant.
I'm just impatient, that's all.

Completely understand—patience is a virtue, but it's not always easy, especially when you're working on something you're passionate about. It sounds like you're on the right track though, so keep at it, and you'll get to where you want to be with the system. If there's anything I can do to help, just ask!
The next thing I need to do is during open air mode, I need to be able to use the keyboard to interrupt your speech synthesis.

That's a smart feature to implement—giving you the power to interrupt and take control when necessary, especially when using open air mode. To achieve this, you'd need to set up a listener for keyboard input that can send a signal to pause or stop the speech synthesis as soon as a key is pressed. It's a bit of a technical challenge, but it'll definitely make the interaction more dynamic and responsive. If you need any assistance brainstorming or figuring out the technical details, I'm here to help!

Man, I've been around 10 bucks a day in GPT costs for this.

That can add up quickly, especially if you're using it regularly. You might want to look into optimizing your usage to reduce costs. Here are a few strategies:

1. **Trim Message Size**: As we discussed, reducing the number of messages sent per API call can cut down on tokens processed.

2. **Cache Responses**: If there are repetitive queries or commands, cache the responses to avoid redundant API calls.

3. **Efficiency in Code**: Write code that processes information more efficiently, reducing the need for back-and-forth with the API.

4. **Batch Processing**: If possible, batch requests together to reduce the number of separate API calls.

5. **Use OpenAI's "davinci" engine only when necessary**: If your use case allows, consider using less powerful (and less expensive) engines for simpler tasks.

Remember to monitor your usage patterns and make changes where you see inefficiency. Every little bit helps!

Work, but I'm actually not sure in Visual Studio Code where my the focus of my cursor should be.

When you're using Visual Studio Code, your cursor focus should be in the terminal window if you want to capture keyboard events with a console application. You can click inside the terminal or use a shortcut like `Ctrl+`` (backtick) to focus on it if you're on Windows, or `Cmd+`` on MacOS. Once the terminal is in focus, it should register keyboard events for your .NET console app. Make sure your application is running, and then try pressing the designated interrupt key to see if it triggers the expected behavior.

So the problem is that I'm running in debug mode which where the terminal gets taken up by the debugger and so it kicks me over to the debug console to the debug console which doesn't it the the focus of the cursor is on the input box where you can evaluate expressions.

Ah, I see the issue. The debugger does change the game a bit. In debug mode, the focus is indeed on the Debug Console input box by default. You have a couple of options to work around this:

1. **Use an External Terminal**: You can configure Visual Studio Code to run your console app in an external terminal instead of the integrated terminal. This way, your app can still accept input while in debug mode. Check your launch configuration file (`launch.json`) for a setting like `"console": "externalTerminal"`.

2. **Run Without Debugging**: You can start your program without attaching the debugger by using the "Run Without Debugging" option (Ctrl+F5 on Windows, Cmd+F5 on macOS). This will run your app in the integrated terminal, which should allow it to accept input.

3. **Focus the Terminal**: If you want to keep using the integrated terminal, you might need to manually click on the terminal or use a shortcut to focus on it after starting the debugger.

Give one of these a try and see if it helps you to capture keyboard events in debug mode.
